text: What is the current end-to-end architecture with tech stack (sources -> ETL -> reporting)?
Where is the platform hosted (on-prem / cloud / hybrid)?
What is the approximate data volume processed (daily/monthly)?
Are data layers clearly defined (raw / curated / reporting), or mostly point-to-point ETL?
Is there a single orchestration tool giving visibility across the 3000 jobs?
What are the top 3 causes of job failures (data quality, late files, infra, code)?
How are failures detected and re-run today (manual vs automated)?
Are there batch window or SLA issues for regulatory or finance reporting?
Is the primary pain point today dev & maintenance effort, or ops & support effort (job monitoring, failures, reruns)?
What ETL technologies are used (vendor tools vs custom/in-house code)?
What % of ETL is in-house developed, why?
How are Bitbucket and Aldon used today, and where is the biggest friction?
How strong is data lineage and audit traceability (BCBS 239 readiness)?
How is test data created, and what automation exists for regression testing?
Approximately how many distinct reports are produced from these ~3000 jobs (regulatory, risk, finance)?
Are reports strictly batch, or is near-real-time / intraday required for any use cases?
What would define success (fewer jobs, fewer failures, faster change, better auditability)?
Is the bank using any modern Lakehouse like Databricks or Snowflake?
